description:
You can sit back and relax. It’s not like being trapped on long-haul flights because you’re still moving around.

But you might want to watch what you’re eating and be mindful of growing old – obesity and ageing are going to put you at risk of DVT.

Link in bio for the details. #WFH #workfromhome #DVT #deepveinthrombosis #obesity #ageing #health (Photo: Freepik)

description:

comments: No need work from home, work outside
description:
Using a low coffee table as your desk, typing on the laptop in bed, sharing your child’s crowded study desk to keep an eye on his home-based learning while you reply emails … those are some of the positions we find ourselves in this new WFH era.

And this is causing a lot of problems. Doctors shared they’ve been seeing a rise in patients with WFH-related injuries – whether it’s backaches or sprains – every month. Here’s how to tweak your home office setup to make you more comfortable.

LAPTOP: The best way to set up your laptop is on a table – and not balanced on your lap. Raise it by 5 to 10 inches (13cm to 25cm) with paper reams or laptop raisers to achieve the proper height.

MONITOR: If you’re using an external monitor or have two freestanding monitors at home, make sure they are of the same size and height. Place the monitors directly in front of you to avoid vision and neck problems – at least an arm’s length away (about 45cm to 70cm) at eye level.

KEYBOARD & MOUSE: Use a separate keyboard and mouse when using a laptop – preferably a low-profile keyboard not more than 3cm high and with an incline angle of less than 15 degrees to maintain your wrists’ neutral position. When typing, the elbows should be maintained at a 90-degree-to-120-degree bend with the forearms resting on the table or armrest. Your mouse should fit your palm and kept close to the keyboard.

CHAIR: If you don’t want to splurge on an ergonomic chair, get a cushion or lumbar support for your regular chair. But whatever chair you use, it should be stable and adjustable so that your knees and hips are kept at 90 degrees. Use one with armrests, a backrest, and enough height for your feet to lay flat on the floor or be supported by a footrest to reduce pressure on the thighs.

Read more on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #worktips #work #backache #WFH #homeoffice #worklifebalance (Photo: Freepik)

comments: Itsok our school got wipe down
description:
While many of us are still working from home, some have gone back to the office – which means staying extra careful.

According to the World Health Organization, contamination on surfaces touched by colleagues and visitors is one of the main ways that COVID-19 spreads in the workplace.

While your company might already employ professional cleaners, it pays to do a bit of cleaning yourself, since they might miss certain areas. Before even switching on your computer, wipe down the following: Start button of your computer/laptop, keyboard, mouse, office phone, desktop, your chair’s armrests and the top of the seat’s backing where you usually grab to move the chair, and stationery such as stapler, correction fluid and pens.

Pay attention to areas that come into frequent contact with your hands, mouth and nose such as the telephone, keyboard and computer mouse. It’s advisable to wipe these with a disinfectant at least three times a day: At the start of the day, midday and before you get off work.
Read the full story on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #office #work #hygiene #cleaningtips (Photo: Freepik)

comments: just have more sex. lose weight.
description:
After a couple of months of minimal to non-existent exercise thanks to the circuit breaker, everyone’s probably raring to get back into shape. But you’ll need to be careful not to shock your body by immediately going back to your pre-CB regimen.

Inactivity means your fitness levels have gone down – culminating in weight gain if you haven’t been exercising for eight weeks. But don’t worry, fitness loss is reversible – when you start exercising regularly again, it will return.

The key is to put aside your ego, and start slow and easy. Don’t assume that you are still as fit as your old self. If you don’t feel comfortable any exercises, slow down, reduce the resistance or do fewer repetitions. As a rule of the thumb, resume your activities at half the intensity, frequency, and duration relative to what you used to do. Over the weeks, progressively step up the intensity by 10 per cent each week.

To find out if your starting point is excessive, take note of your post-exercise aches and soreness. If you do not experience any soreness or muscle aches, it is likely that you were too conservative. If you experience excessive soreness and have difficulty going about your daily activities, it is likely that you were too ambitious with your fitness routine. If the soreness is bearable and you can comfortably go about your daily activities, you have struck the right balance.

Read the full story on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #exercise #fitness #circuitbreaker #Singapore #workout #weightgain #weightloss (Photo: Pexels)

If the soreness is bearable and you can comfortably go about your daily activities, you have struck the right balance.

description:
After a couple of months of minimal to non-existent exercise thanks to the circuit breaker, everyone’s probably raring to get back into shape. But you’ll need to be careful not to shock your body by immediately going back to your pre-CB regimen.

Inactivity means your fitness levels have gone down – culminating in weight gain if you haven’t been exercising for eight weeks. But don’t worry, fitness loss is reversible – when you start exercising regularly again, it will return.

The key is to put aside your ego, and start slow and easy. Don’t assume that you are still as fit as your old self. If you don’t feel comfortable any exercises, slow down, reduce the resistance or do fewer repetitions. As a rule of the thumb, resume your activities at half the intensity, frequency, and duration relative to what you used to do. Over the weeks, progressively step up the intensity by 10 per cent each week.

To find out if your starting point is excessive, take note of your post-exercise aches and soreness. If you do not experience any soreness or muscle aches, it is likely that you were too conservative. If you experience excessive soreness and have difficulty going about your daily activities, it is likely that you were too ambitious with your fitness routine. If the soreness is bearable and you can comfortably go about your daily activities, you have struck the right balance.

Read the full story on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #exercise #fitness #circuitbreaker #Singapore #workout #weightgain #weightloss (Photo: Pexels)

comments: I believe this crisis brings out the worse and best of humanity. We can choose to look at it as a challenge and also to look at it as a chance to grow. Its tough but I know we eventually can get through this. I truly see unity and love in Singapore during this pandemic and its like a miraculous re-emergence of the kampong spirit!
description:
Work from home. Home-based learning. No bubble tea. We’ve been adjusting to one big change after another because of COVID-19. But do some people find it hard to accept the changes and how does one stay resilient in unusual times like these?

We talked to some health experts on how to cope with our fluctuating lives and accept the reality check that things will probably never go back to the way things were before. Among some helpful tips to stay resilient include establishing a daily routine to reduce anxiety, engaging in a particular activity or hobby to help us be in control and focused, and to stay socially connected with others – even if it’s online for now.

Read the entire story on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #circuitbreaker #anxiety #change #realitycheck #mentalhealth #staystrong #resilience (Photo: Pexels)

It’s May 11 and we all know what that means – McDonald’s Singapore is finally open again. Or at least most of its restaurants – and only for deliveries, drive-through services and takeaways.

After a three-week absence, it’s now taking orders. But there are some caveats: Most will be open from 7am to 9pm, and those located in parks, tourist attractions and some institutions will remain closed. It will also not be offering 24-hour service and its dessert kiosks and McCafe counters will remain closed due to the “circuit breaker” rules. But we’ll take it!

Read more on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #McDonalds #Singapore #fastfood #circuitbreaker (Photo: Instagram/McDonald’s)

With everyone stuck at home, it might not seem like the perfect time to socialise. But with everyone virtually connected and social norms undergoing a huge change, it might actually a good time to say hello to a former friend you've lost in touch with.

Although moments of reconnection can be powerful, we often miss out on them. The mere thought of reaching out can make us uncomfortable, ie, there's a "reason" you haven't talked. But in most cases, it's because we get busy, we change jobs, we move. We didn’t mean to fall out of touch. In one study, many people felt anxious before reconnecting, but 90 per cent reported afterward that it was fun and enjoyable.

And you've got an excuse now. “People think it will be awkward or unwanted if they pick up the phone and call an old friend they haven’t spoken to in years,” Dan Gilbert, a professor of psychology at Harvard University, said. “But in this time of crisis, reaching out is even easier because there is a very natural opener: Calling to see if you and your family are okay?” Read more about why you should message your long-lost friend on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #friends #reconnect #relationship #advice #lifelessons #stayconnected (Photo: Pexels)

description:
With everyone stuck at home, it might not seem like the perfect time to socialise. But with everyone virtually connected and social norms undergoing a huge change, it might actually a good time to say hello to a former friend you've lost in touch with.

Although moments of reconnection can be powerful, we often miss out on them. The mere thought of reaching out can make us uncomfortable, ie, there's a "reason" you haven't talked. But in most cases, it's because we get busy, we change jobs, we move. We didn’t mean to fall out of touch. In one study, many people felt anxious before reconnecting, but 90 per cent reported afterward that it was fun and enjoyable.

And you've got an excuse now. “People think it will be awkward or unwanted if they pick up the phone and call an old friend they haven’t spoken to in years,” Dan Gilbert, a professor of psychology at Harvard University, said. “But in this time of crisis, reaching out is even easier because there is a very natural opener: Calling to see if you and your family are okay?” Read more about why you should message your long-lost friend on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #friends #reconnect #relationship #advice #lifelessons #stayconnected (Photo: Pexels)

What do you do when you’re inside but you want to be outside without actually going outside? For two Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts (NAFA) graduates, the answer was to design a home modelled closely after a classic HDB void deck.

About two weeks into the “circuit breaker” period, they imagined this clever design and posted the images to their Facebook and Instagram pages, Creatology. The pictures were captioned: “When your interior designer really wants to go out and lepak.” Read more on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio! #Singapore #homes #HDB #voiddeck #interiordesign #smartliving (Photos: Creatology)

The pictures were captioned: “When your interior designer really wants to go out and lepak.” Read more on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio! #Singapore #homes #HDB #voiddeck #interiordesign #smartliving (Photos: Creatology)

When hawker Melvin Chew heard Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong’s first “circuit breaker” announcement in early April, he knew he had to do something for his fellow hawkers. “I foresaw that many hawkers who are used to relying on walk-in customers will now need help to promote their stalls on social media," said the second-gen owner of Jin Ji Teochew Braised Duck & Kway Chap stall at Chinatown Complex Food Centre.

Most hawkers aren’t on conventional delivery services such as Grab, Food Panda and Deliveroo – and many don’t even have any social media accounts. The result was the Facebook group Hawkers United – Dabao 2020, which allows hawkers to promote their food and arrange for takeaway or delivery. Since it was set up, the group has had more than 200,000 members, hawkers and patrons alike.

It’s proven so popular that spin-off groups have also been launched, such as Pasar United (for retailers) and Delivery United (for delivery folks). There’s also a Hawkers United Singapore website that groups hawker stalls based on different geographical areas to make things even easier for everyone.

Read more about the story on CNA Lifestyle and, even more important, check out the pages to find out how you can help your favourite hawkers (and eat your favourite dishes). Link in bio! #Singapore #hawker #food #hawkersunited #community #inspiration (Photo: Melvin Chew)

comments: They should hold a rock concert when this is over so that we can sway our long hairs. Rock On.🤘
description:
Singapore’s “circuit breaker” period has been extended to June 1. But if you were thinking of ordering online a nice, refreshing cup of bubble tea to comfort yourself, that might be hard.

The list of essential services that will stay open during this period have been trimmed even further. That means specialised food and beverage outlets will have to shut for now, including outlets that “predominantly” sell drinks like bubble tea, fruit juice, smoothies, coffee, soya bean and alcoholic drinks. Popcorn stores, bak kwa shops, ice cream shops, outlets that mainly sell cakes, cupcakes, cheese and other desserts will have to close too.

And if you’ve got zero shaving skills, you might have to resign yourself to growing your hair out this circuit breaker period), as hairdressers and barbers will have to close their outlets. Read our story on what you can or cannot do under tighter circuit breaker rules on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #Singapore #circuitbreaker #bubbletea #coronavirus #COVID19 (Photo: Unsplash)

Read our story on what you can or cannot do under tighter circuit breaker rules on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #Singapore #circuitbreaker #bubbletea #coronavirus #COVID19 (Photo: Unsplash)

description:
McDonald's Singapore will suspend restaurant operations in all its outlets from Apr 19 until the end of the "circuit breaker" period.

In a press release, it said: "McDonald’s Singapore today announced it has been advised by the Ministry of Health that as a preventative action in the fight against COVID-19 in Singapore, it is suspending restaurant operations, including McDelivery and Drive-Thru, till May 4." This move - which includes drive-through and delivery services - went into effect from 11am Sunday, and comes a day after the fast food chain announced the suspension of takeaways.

In announcing its previous move to suspend takeaways, the company said that it would continue to pay salaries of employees, including seniors, whose roles will be disrupted during this period. There are seven McDonald's employees infected with COVID-19 to date. #McDonalds #Singapore #fastfood #circuitbreaker #coronavirus #COVID19

There are seven McDonald's employees infected with COVID-19 to date. #McDonalds #Singapore #fastfood #circuitbreaker #coronavirus #COVID19

description:
McDonald's Singapore will suspend restaurant operations in all its outlets from Apr 19 until the end of the "circuit breaker" period.

In a press release, it said: "McDonald’s Singapore today announced it has been advised by the Ministry of Health that as a preventative action in the fight against COVID-19 in Singapore, it is suspending restaurant operations, including McDelivery and Drive-Thru, till May 4." This move - which includes drive-through and delivery services - went into effect from 11am Sunday, and comes a day after the fast food chain announced the suspension of takeaways.

In announcing its previous move to suspend takeaways, the company said that it would continue to pay salaries of employees, including seniors, whose roles will be disrupted during this period. There are seven McDonald's employees infected with COVID-19 to date. #McDonalds #Singapore #fastfood #circuitbreaker #coronavirus #COVID19

For couples staying together, the current stay-at-home situation might seem like the perfect romantic scenario. Unfortunately, many may not have experienced living together for extended periods such as what we’re experiencing right now.

From the heightened anxiety because of the pandemic, to the shrinking of personal space and personal time, to deep-seated and unresolved issues floating around, it's not surprising for people to develop cabin fever relationship-wise.

The first thing to do is make sure you have a bit of personal time in, hopefully, your own personal space. You don't have to spend every single minute together. For more advice from our counselling experts, read our story on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #relationships #advice #couples #coupling #tips #love #isolation (Photo: Unsplash)

comments: Tip is “Marie Kondo” your place and you won’t feel so frustrated

description:
Everyone’s working from home – and that includes a famous street artist like Banksy.

Unable to go out and spray on walls, he’s taken to creating a new artwork in his bathroom. He recently posted a photo on his Instagram account with the quip: “My wife hates it when I work from home.” It features his trademark stenciled rats running amok around the sink and toilet.

The big question is – does he still wear a mask at home? #Banksy #workfromhome #streetart #artist #graffiti #coronavirus #COVID19 (Photos: Instagram/Banksy)

It’s circuit breaker time, so we can’t go out drinking with friends – but it doesn’t mean we can’t still have cocktails and conversation with them over a video call. ❤️ CNA Lifestyle’s Phin Wong and Genevieve Loh try out home-delivered cocktails over a Zoom happy hour session. #stayhome #staysafe #staysane #CNAlifestyle @drinksundaypunch @kikisreserve @elephantroomsg @theoldman_sg @the.secret.mermaid @nativebarsg @nutmegandclove

comments: Jason and Zhen Long,Very proud of you two!!!We need more kind- hearted souls like you guys👏👏👏👏👏👍👍👍!!!
description:
Jason Chua, 28, and partner Hung Zhen Long, 27, are the guys behind “creative zhap cai png” stall, Beng Who Cooks. Ever since circuit breaker measures kicked in, business has dropped 80 per cent. But they’re still giving away free food to help those who can’t afford to eat.

Under their Beng Who Cares Foundation, those in need can simply claim a free meal, no questions asked. All the pair needs is the address to deliver to.

Are they worried about being taken advantage of? Said Jason: “If people really resort to such things, then deep down, they really need that help.” Link in bio for details. (Photo: @bengwhocooks ) #covidkindness #singapore

description: Support local: You may not be able to dine out during the circuit breaker period, but you can still support your favourite food places by ordering a meal in! From homegrown restaurants to your favourite hawker stalls, eateries and cafes, CNA Lifestyle has put together a list of the makan places with delivery services and deals. Link in bio, and check back often as the list will be updated regularly! #dinein #stayhome #takeaway #delivery #Singapore #hawker #hawkerfood #cafes #restaurants #CNAlifestyle (Pic: Instagram/itsyalin)

Restaurants in MBS have donated perishable food products, including bread, vegetables, fruit, meat, dairy products and 3,600 eggs to The Food Bank Singapore ahead of the integrated resort’s one-month closure during the nationwide “circuit breaker” campaign to curb the further spread of COVID-19. The charity collects excess food from food suppliers and re-distributes them to organisations such as old folks' homes, family service centres and soup kitchens. "We may be pausing action, but we hope our donated food will fill up the tables of the underprivileged and keep them warm and full during these unprecedented times,” said Christine Sheares, vice president, F&B, Marina Bay Sands. Just in time, it seems. Nicholas Ng, co-founder of The Food Bank Singapore, said its donations and volunteer involvement have been badly affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. #MBS #marinabaysands #singapore #covid19 #covid #covidkindness #corona #coronavirus #CNAlifestyle (Photo: @marinabaysands )

Nicholas Ng, co-founder of The Food Bank Singapore, said its donations and volunteer involvement have been badly affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. #MBS #marinabaysands #singapore #covid19 #covid #covidkindness #corona #coronavirus #CNAlifestyle (Photo: @marinabaysands )

Restaurants in MBS have donated perishable food products, including bread, vegetables, fruit, meat, dairy products and 3,600 eggs to The Food Bank Singapore ahead of the integrated resort’s one-month closure during the nationwide “circuit breaker” campaign to curb the further spread of COVID-19. The charity collects excess food from food suppliers and re-distributes them to organisations such as old folks' homes, family service centres and soup kitchens. "We may be pausing action, but we hope our donated food will fill up the tables of the underprivileged and keep them warm and full during these unprecedented times,” said Christine Sheares, vice president, F&B, Marina Bay Sands. While many were out and about busy stocking up on stuff before Singapore's "circuit breaker" measures kick in on Apr 7, actress Rebecca Lim was also seen going around different parts of the island this weekend.

But instead of shopping, she and a friend were giving away 400 care packs for the elderly and frontline heroes in essential services, with some help from sponsors. Aside from going door-to-door, Lim also handed out care packs to taxi drivers, cleaners and construction workers.

She wrote on Instagram: "I hope you spread love and choose kindness. We will get there. #SGcares #SGUnited." #RebeccaLim #Singapore #charity #helping #circuitbreaker #coronavirus #COVID19 (Photos: Instagram/Rebecca Lim)

description:
While many were out and about busy stocking up on stuff before Singapore's "circuit breaker" measures kick in on Apr 7, actress Rebecca Lim was also seen going around different parts of the island this weekend.

But instead of shopping, she and a friend were giving away 400 care packs for the elderly and frontline heroes in essential services, with some help from sponsors. Aside from going door-to-door, Lim also handed out care packs to taxi drivers, cleaners and construction workers.

She wrote on Instagram: "I hope you spread love and choose kindness. We will get there. #SGcares #SGUnited." #RebeccaLim #Singapore #charity #helping #circuitbreaker #coronavirus #COVID19 (Photos: Instagram/Rebecca Lim)

description:
In the age of safe distancing and belt tightening, F&B players in Singapore say the industry is hanging by a thread.

The urgent need for support from landlords is a sentiment many restaurant owners share. “There is so much rental pressure on restaurants where the operating cash flow is just two months out. If restaurants and retailers don’t get help from landlords, we cannot survive. (The landlords) have made so much money from us tenants over the last few years and now is the time they really have to step up to help us,” said Cynthia Chua of Spa Esprit Group, which includes establishments like Tiong Bahru Bakery.

Substantial rentals are not the only challenge facing Singapore’s restaurants today. “There’s a lot of uncertainty as to when produce is coming in. Right now, we can get fish locally or from Malaysia, but with meat (mostly from Australia), the worry is what will happen when stocks here run out” said Cheek and Cloudstreet chef-owner Rishi Naleendra.

But the greatest challenge is the lack of traffic. Relish’s Willin Low said: “If people stop coming out, then there’s no point in keeping a restaurant open.” Read the story on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #Singapore #food #restaurant #F&B #coronavirus #COVID19 #safedistancing #socialdistancing (Photo: Instagram/Tiong Bahru Bakery)

description:
In the age of safe distancing and belt tightening, F&B players in Singapore say the industry is hanging by a thread.

The urgent need for support from landlords is a sentiment many restaurant owners share. “There is so much rental pressure on restaurants where the operating cash flow is just two months out. If restaurants and retailers don’t get help from landlords, we cannot survive. (The landlords) have made so much money from us tenants over the last few years and now is the time they really have to step up to help us,” said Cynthia Chua of Spa Esprit Group, which includes establishments like Tiong Bahru Bakery.

Substantial rentals are not the only challenge facing Singapore’s restaurants today. “There’s a lot of uncertainty as to when produce is coming in. Right now, we can get fish locally or from Malaysia, but with meat (mostly from Australia), the worry is what will happen when stocks here run out” said Cheek and Cloudstreet chef-owner Rishi Naleendra.

But the greatest challenge is the lack of traffic. Relish’s Willin Low said: “If people stop coming out, then there’s no point in keeping a restaurant open.” Read the story on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #Singapore #food #restaurant #F&B #coronavirus #COVID19 #safedistancing #socialdistancing (Photo: Instagram/Tiong Bahru Bakery)

If you’ve been working from home because your company has implemented segregation plans because of the coronavirus, you might be loving the convenience of it all.

But if you’re not careful, you’re actually putting on weight just because snacks are more within your reach. All that munching might lead to a half-kilo of weight gained a week, according to health experts. Especially if you’re already a frequent snacker in the office.

How do you balance it out? Try and sneak in some active time in your work routine, like a quick walk during your breaks, drinking more water – and if you’re up for it, maybe even some pushups during commercials when you’re watching a bit of TV. Read more tips on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #work #home #worklifebalance #weightgain #health #tips (Photo: Unsplash)
